introduction.p: In , we used linear regression to fit a line to a collection of data points. If the data points do not cluster around a line, it does not make sense to describe them by a linear function. Compare the scatterplots in . scatterplot that is linear and another that falls on a parabola

The points in a are roughly linear in appearance, but the points in b are not. However, we can visualize a parabola that would approximate the data we will. In this section, we will see how to fit a quadratic function to a collection of data points.
We will need to solve a special type of 3 \times 3 linear system, that is, a linear system of three equations in three variables. We can solve these systems using the eliminationelimination method.

solution.p: We first eliminate c from the system by combining the equations in pairs. We can add -1 times Equation (2) to Equation (1) to get a new equation in two variables:

Next, we add -1 times Equation (2) to Equation (3) to get a second equation in two variables:

By combining Equations (4) and (5), we have a 2 \times 2 linear system, which we can solve as usual.
\begin{alignedat}{9} 2a \amp {}+{} \amp 4b \amp {}={} \amp 2\amp\hphantom{blankblank}\amp(4) \\ a \amp {}+{} \amp 5b \amp {}={} \amp 7\amp\amp(5) \end{alignedat}
To eliminate a, we add -2 times Equation (5) to Equation (4):

Solving this last equation gives us b = 2. Then we substitute b = 2 into either of Equations (4) or (5) to find a = -3. Finally, we substitute both values into one of the three original equations to find c = 4. The solution of the system is a = -3, b = 2, c = 4.

subsection.title: Finding a Quadratic Function through Three Points
subsection.p: Every linear function can be written in the form y = mx + b To find a specific line, we must find values for the two parameters (constants) m and b. We need two data points in order to find those two parameters. A quadratic function, however, has three parameters, a, b, and c: y = ax^2 + bx + c To find these parameters, we need three data points. We then use the method of elimination to solve a system of three linear equations.

subsection.p: The simplest way to fit a parabola to a set of data points is to pick three of the points and find the equation of the parabola that passes through those three points.

subsection.title: Finding an Equation in Vertex Form
subsection.p: It is easier to find a quadratic model if one of the points we know happens to be the vertex of the parabola. In that case, we need only one other point, and we can use the vertex form to find its equation.

technology.p: We can use a graphing calculator to find an approximate quadratic fit for a set of data. The procedure is similar to the steps for linear regression outlined in .

example.p: Francine records the height of the tip of the minute hand on the classroom’s clock at different times. The data are shown in the table, where time is measured in minutes since noon. (A negative time indicates a number of minutes before noon.) Find a quadratic regression equation for the data and use it to predict the height of the minute hand's tip at 40 minutes past noon. Do you believe this prediction is valid?

solution.p: We enter the time data under L_1 and the height data under L_2. Then we calculate and store the quadratic regression equation in Y_1, as we did in . The regression equation is y = -0.00297x2 + 0x + 8.834 From either the graph of the regression equation or from the table (see figure below), we can see that the fit is not perfect, although the curve certainly fits the data better than any straight line could.

image.description: GC screens of graph and tables for quadratic fit

solution.p: If we scroll down the table, we find that this equation predicts a height of approximately 4.08 feet at time 40 minutes. (See figure c.) This is a preposterous estimate! The position of the minute hand at 40 minutes after noon should be the same as it was exactly one hour earlier (at 20 minutes before noon), when it was 7.50 feet.

subsection.p: Using the wrong type of equation to fit the data is a common error in making predictions. We know that the minute hand of a clock repeats its position every 60 minutes. The graph of the height of its tip oscillates up and down, repeating the same pattern over and over. We cannot describe such a graph using either a linear or a quadratic equation.

image.description: parabola fit on part of a periodic wave

sidebyside.p: The graph of the height is shown in , along with the graph of our quadratic regression equation. You can see that the regression equation fits the actual curve only on a small interval.

subsection.p: Your calculator can always compute a regression equation, but that equation is not necessarily appropriate for your data. Choosing a reasonable type of regression equation for a particular data set requires knowledge of different kinds of models and the physical or natural laws that govern the situation at hand.
